You likely had an episode of some sort since you were “extremely tired.” Maybe see your doctor about this and explain to them what happened?

This doesn’t explain your glitch, but just as a PSA — It‘s so important to pull over immediately when you start feeling the “can’t keep my eyes open” tiredness. That is the first stage of sleep, and you’re already losing your ability to keep yourself in control of your vehicle. Sometimes the relief of knowing you’re “almost there” is all it takes to relax you into full sleep. 

I grew up being taught all the tricks like opening a window, drinking a cold soda, turning up the radio, etc. I pushed these sleepy driving moments too far before one day, I was “suddenly” in a ditch on top of a street sign. I had babies in the car with me. Never again!

That's really odd. Have you tried having a go at remembering a little past being at the light / just before seeing the sign? It can be easiest to catch that sort of memory as you're on the edge of drifting to sleep.

likely_demographics: Adults (30-50 years old) likely with families, potentially interested in paranormal activities or mysteries.  They value shared experiences and discussions.  May live in suburban or rural areas based on anecdotal locations.
generated_from_cluster: Had the hours of Saturday evening pass in a similar manner with three friends.  We weren't on psychedelics or drugs.  But the entire evening flew by with the hours passing like minutes.

I swear just the other day something similar happened to me. I went outside to smoke a cigarette (I know, I shouldn't, but anyways...), I read an article or 2, it felt like about 20 minutes. I'd gone outside at 11pm. A show was on TV streaming, 20 minute episodes, no ads, a series I've seen countless times before.  So when I got back inside, the next episode was just starting, which aligned with my approximate 20 minute estimate of time outside.  But all the clocks (analog, digital, battery run, as well as plugged in, every clock, even my cell phone), suddenly showed it was past 1pm. Over 2 hours had gone by. But only the one 20 minute show had played on TV. My kids were inside and confirmed the TV never paused or shut off the show. So somehow over 2 hours had passed, while I smoked one cigarette and while only one 20 minute TV show had played.  I'd even told the kids before i went out, that it was 11pm, getting late, they'd have to go to bed when I got back in. None of us could figure out how over 2 hours has gone by. I'd normally NEVER let my kids stay up past 1am, even on summer non-school nights. I'd forgotten about it till I just read your post. Spooky stuff...

So wait, you've come to this space and observed for hours at a time on multiple occasions...? And the people are always the same? Or it's different characters but those doing their own loops somewhat synced with a couple others??

This happened to me in 2018. My husband and I were driving to Los Lunas from Albuquerque which should take 45 min, an hour tops. We stopped once for about 5 minutes and bought a coke, no one else was in line. 
Anyway, the map kept saying 15 more minutes for what seemed like FOREVER... But we weren't checking our phones because we were talking, listening to music and just not paying attention to the time. Anyway, the person we were going to see finally texts and is like... I thought you said you were on the way??? We were supposed to be there by about 1, and it was now 4:30... We have no idea what happened. We didn't turn off anywhere, we didn't stop anywhere else, we didn't get stuck in traffic. And on the way back, it took about 40 minutes exactly. So fucking weird

generated_from_cluster: Deja vu a lot of times. But time skipping never.
All the time, but mine was related to severe early childhood trauma, and followed all my life. Still happens from time to time, in my early 50s now.
A time slip? Scary and cool at the same time.

This story seriously reminds me of the famous 1979 “Liverpool Time Slip” case. Two men, Frank and Geoff, were walking along Bold Street when they suddenly found themselves in what appeared to be the 1950s—complete with vintage storefronts, cars, and people in period clothing. One of them even claimed to walk into an old-fashioned shop and interact with people before snapping back to present day. What’s wild is that later investigation showed the shop he thought he entered (Debenhams) used to actually be a clothing store in that exact location during the 1950s. He even described the interior in stunning detail.

Just like your experience, there was no portal or beam of light—just a subtle but inexplicable moment where the rules of time and space didn’t seem to apply. The fact that you recognized one of the people as your dad’s younger self and only confirmed it later through photo hits the same eerie note.

Maybe these glitches are less full-on time travel and more like overlaps in the simulation—brief moments where time folds or data crosswires. Emotionally charged memories or locations can also act like magnets for these phenomena.

Reports like yours make an intriguing case. Thanks for sharing. Very cool.
Yes, I agree with Liverpool comment but wow! To experience that must have been incredible- especially having confirmation from your dad. How did you feel at the time (anything different?)

The brain is powerful, your memory of them projected them in “real time” to view.

That must have been a very confusing moment for you, so it’s completely understandable that you didn’t have the bandwidth.. or even the idea of how to confront the situation at the time. And now it’s troubling you, but the moment has passed. Just know that it was meant to happen exactly the way it did. You couldn’t have changed it.

Maybe your life is in some kind of loop and this is something that keeps repeating across lifetimes .. or maybe not. Perhaps it was a one-off glitch, something that wasn’t supposed to happen but did anyway. In a strange way, maybe it’s a good thing that you and your younger self didn’t actually meet or touch. That might have really messed things up.

I wanted to ask though.. do you live in the same house now as you did when you were younger? If you’ve moved, maybe your younger self is living in that original place. You could try watching him from afar to see if everything else matches up. I wouldn’t usually advise this, but since this is really affecting you, it might offer some clarity.

Just be careful not to meet him or let him see you. That could create a paradox and you don’t want to risk things spiraling out of control.
